Description: Wheel-made pottery oil-lamp with a low body, a central point and a wide overhanging rim with a beaded outer edge, which slopes in towards the centre. The tapering nozzle has a rounded tip and a large oval wick-hole. The underside is turned. Nozzle glazed matt black. Soot on nozzle is extensive and the whole oil-lamp is stained dark brown. Light brown fabric.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar form from Athens (Howland 1958, no. 156), South Ionian parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 1975, Q146-9). Bailey suggested a similar piece may have been made in Naukratis (Bailey 1975, 198), however an East Greece origin seems more likely. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.26) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5762 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
